text: She has big blue eyes, a small nose and a big mouth.
Her hair is blonde, long and straight.
He has small green eyes, a big nose and a small mouth.
His hair is brown, short and curly.
Look at the mirror, draw your face or paste a picture of you there.
Great! Now write a report about your classmate.
Use the model below to help you.
I will introduce my friend to you.
Introduce your classmate to the rest of the group.
Have a look at our classroom.
One picture is after the Math class.
The other picture is after the English class.
Find the differences between the two pictures.
In pic A there is an eraser on the table,
in pic B there is an eraser on the chair.
AT THE END OF THIS UNIT, YOU WILL BE ABLE TO
recognize types of houses by reading and listening to different descriptions.
name objects in a bedroom and refer to their location.
organize new vocabulary by creating a picture dictionary.
reflect and talk about your favorite toy from your childhood.
get acquainted with vocabulary related to clothing.
distinguish between winter and summer clothes.
describe your and your partners’ outfits.
Nico introduced himself. Now, it’s your turn. Complete this chart.
The teacher asks you to learn more about one of your classmates.
Get in pairs and ask him / her about his / her personal information.
Match the colors with the names on the palette.
Get in pairs. Ask and answer.
Let's play a game! Come and guess the objects from the bag.
Then, write the objects on the chart.
There are some objects in the bag.
One member of the group goes to the front of the class.
He / she touches the object and describes it to his / her group.
It is big. / It is small.
I think you can eat it.
Write the objects your group and the other group guessed.
Look at Nico, Lua and Emma and answer their questions.
My name is Emma. What’s your name?
I am 13. How old are you?
My favorite color is blue. What’s your favorite color?
Now write a general description of your house.
If you want include a picture.
Emma is learning the different parts of the house in English.
She has some definitions and the names. Match them.
In this room there is a fridge and you can cook.
In this room there are sofas and you can watch TV.
In this room there is a bed and you sleep there.
In this room there is a shower and toilet and you can brush your teeth.
From this place you can see the street and the neighborhood.
In this room there is a table and there are chairs and you can eat there.
This bubble map is about the text on the previous page.
Create a bubble map about your house.
Can you wait a minute, please?
Can you write the date, please?
Can you come to the board, please?
Use these classroom language phrases and the previous ones.
You talked with Nico, Lua and Emma.
Now write a paragraph about you.
Use this chart to help you.
Hi! / Hello! / Nice to meet you! / Hi there!
Hello! My name is Nico and my last name is Romero.
I am 13 years old and I live in a crowded city in Uruguay.
My father is Ismael and my mother is Teresa.
Look at the feeling good chain of the characters…
All of you stand up and do your own feel good chain.
Write sentences about your feelings today.
e.g. Today, I feel great! I love school and I love my classmates.
These pictures are from some houses in the neighborhood.
Take a look at the different types of houses.
Listen to the description of the houses and write the letter the speaker is referring to.
Which house do they refer to?
Read and listen to check your answers.
Nico and his classmate Luis are at the school door.
Look at their conversation and complete it with the words from the box.
Today is the first day of classes; the teacher is calling the roll.
Emotions can be perceived on your face...
What are the different parts of the head?
We have two new classmates in the class.
Look at the descriptions we wrote of Caroline and Michael.
Draw the interior of your house.
Describe it using the words from the previous exercises and the words from the box.
Use vocabulary from the unit and from the S.O.S. Box.
Rubrics for writing activities at the end of this book.
Take all the words from the S.O.S. Box and find pictures about each place.
Paste the pictures and label them.
Do this regularly when you learn new words.
There is a twin bed in it.
In my bedroom there are more objects.
Link the object with its name.
My sister's bedroom is very messy.
It's difficult for her to find the things.
Are these things in the picture?
Look at the picture and see if the sentences are correct.
a There is a notebook on the desk.
b There is a black book under another book.
c There is a paper bin between the desk and the bed.
d There is a big toy crayon behind the bed.
e There is trash in the paper bin.
f There is a printer in front of the desk.
g There is a night table next to the bed.
Now, it's time to describe your ideal bedroom.
Draw the two places that are not in the previous graphic organizer.
To communicate in English it is important to know how to answer questions.
These are some questions and answers we use all the time.
Challenge! Match the questions with the answers.
Now, roleplay the dialogue with a classmate.
twin, full, queen, king and California king.
Which of these objects do you have in your bedroom?
Describe the objects you have in your room.
This house is small and it only has one floor.
Its walls are white and its roof is yellow.
In this house there is one bedroom, a small kitchen and a bathroom.
This house is a detached one.
There is a kitchen, a dining room, a living room and a bathroom on the ground floor.
There are three bedrooms and another bathroom on the first floor.
This is a five-floor building with ten apartments.
In the apartments there are two bedrooms, a kitchen, a living room and a bathroom.
Both have the same number of rooms.
Each of them has two floors.
There is a kitchen, a dining room, and a living room on the ground floor
and there are three big bedrooms, a study room and another bathroom.
There is an attic on the third floor.
This is the description of the fifth house in this unit.
Is it A, B, C, D or E?
This is a block of apartments.
The buildings are different, some are higher than others and they are painted with a variety of colors.
The highest is orange and its roof is green.
In this building the apartments are small.
In each one there are two bedrooms, a kitchen, a bathroom and a small living room.
It doesn’t have a balcony or a dining room.
In the previous description, there are six rooms/parts of the house.
After reading the text and helping Nico with the activity, what do you remember from the text?
What color is the highest building?
Are all the apartments the same?
When you were a kid, did you have a favorite toy?
Do you have it in your bedroom?
Get with a pair and share your ideas.
Let's watch the trailer of an animated movie!
The story is about a child.
The story is about a city.
The story is about the toys.
The movie is set in Andy's room.
Highlight the objects you think Andy has in his room.
Watch the trailer the teacher will play
Were you right? What objects from the list does Andy have in his room?
Is there a bucket of dolls?
How many beds are there in the bedroom?
What animal toys does Andy have?
Is the window next to the door?
What other things are hanging on the walls?
